TWDTest¶

class extremals.TWDTest(keys=None, name='TWD')[source]¶

Bases: extremals.Test

Returns a Total Weighted Distance test

Parameters:
  • keys (list) – list of columns to use, default None: all columns used
  • name (str) – optional name, default 'TWD'

If data is a dataframe and keys is a list of columns, we can run

twd = xt.TWDTest(keys)
series = twd.Apply(data)

The resulting pandas.Series series has the same index as data. For a row x the corresponding value is

means = data[keys].mean()
series.loc[x] = extremals.TWD(data[keys].loc[x], means, un_stds])

while un_stds is the sequence of un-normalized standard deviations of each column (taking into account NaN values). See TWD. As the value of Series in x is a uniform contribution of errors coming from each column, rows with higher values are somehow special. One can use

bounded_series = xt.OutOfBound(series, [0,0.01])

to extrapolate the 1% higher values. See OutOfBound.

Examples: we consider the dataframe data

twd = xt.TWDTest() # all columns will be used
result = twd.Apply(data)

# result is the sorted series
e    0.102827
h    0.153905
i    0.157379
f    0.282413
d    0.552499
g    0.557941
a    0.602914
c    0.727218
l    1.075787
b    2.024297
Name: TWD, dtype: float64

l and b have higher values. This is consistent with the special values of data.loc['l'] and data.loc['b']

twd3 = xt.TWDTest(keys = ['col3'])
result3 = twd3.Apply(data)

# result3 is the series
e    0.036613
l    0.036613
f    0.198754
a    0.237982
g    0.290286
d    0.337359
c    0.413199
b    0.729637
Name: TWD, dtype: float64

result3 can also be obtained as

abs(xt.ColTest('col3', normalized = True).Apply(data)).sort_values()
